Theresa May will open the way for a delay in Brexit if MPs continue to block the exit deal she is negotiating with Brussels, a move aimed at heading off resignations by about a dozen pro-EU ministers.

After insisting for months that Britain would leave the EU on March 29 without a deal if none could be agreed, the prime minister will on Tuesday offer MPs the chance to take a no-deal Brexit off the table.

BE11:14am

Marks & Spencer and online retailer Ocado are poised to confirm plans for a ground-breaking joint venture as soon as tomorrow, the Evening Standard understands.

M&S will pay Ocado between £800 million and £900 million for a 50% stake in the new concern, giving it a food delivery service for the first time, according to sources close to the deal.

BE11:15am

The two firms - both of whom went to ground on Tuesday - have been in frantic talks for the past month over the tie-up.

Effectively Ocado will be split in two, satisfying the desires of chief executive and co-founder Tim Steiner to focus on licensing its tech with retailers around the world. Over the past year the firm has struck licensing deals with retailers in Sweden, the US and Canada, transforming the share price and putting a £6 billion valuation on the company.

BE11:22am

Sterling's up, FTSE's down, blah blah blah. Here's Deutsche.

BE11:23am

We took off our long sterling recommendation four weeks ago and turned neutral
on the pound. That was because Prime Minister May had abandoned her cross
party approach to ratification and instead adopted a run down the clock strategy
designed to bounce moderate Labour MPs into supporting her deal, or face
a crash Brexit. While ratification and an extension of Article 50 remained our
baseline, this increased the odds of an accidental no deal at the end of March,
and market pricing reflected very limited risks.
Two new pieces of information have made us revise our view. First, our analysis
of the constitutional process showed that it was possible for the UK government
to extend Article 50 right up until the 29th March deadline.1 Previously we had
been concerned that extension might only be possible only with a complex and
potentially lengthy parliamentary process.

A. M. @Soundbuy/Fletcher -- perhaps he has something there, but it's better kept out of sight.
FATDAZ @red indeed, if it went ahead would they ditch even more of the non food range/ stores I wonder
BE11:23am

Instead, with the UK able to ask for an extension up until the last minute (and
assuming goodwill from the EU27), a no deal Brexit will only be possible at the
end of March should the UK government actively adopt it as a policy. We think
this is unlikely. As well as causing a split in the Conservative Party, the formation
of the Independent Group of MPs would now imply a material risk of a successful
confidence vote in the government in those circumstances. Last night, headlines
suggested that Prime Minister May would formally ask to rule out a no deal Brexit
by the end of March in her cabinet today. The probability of an 'accidental' no
deal Brexit at the end of March thus now looks very low.
Second, coordination among moderate pro deal Conservative MPs appears to be
improving, partly as a result of the formation of the new Independent Group in
Parliament. In particular, three senior cabinet members suggested they could vote
for an amendment to be tabled this week which would require the government to
ask for an extension of Article 50 should a revised deal with the EU27 not emerge
by 13th March. A similar motion has been proposed by Brexit supporting moderate
Conservative MPs for this week's vote (the Percy/Hart amendment), although it
would not bind the government to the same extent.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

In summary, the 'deal or no deal' choice we had seen taking place in March is
evolving into a 'deal or delay' choice. At a minimum, this should take the risk of a
no deal Brexit by the end of next month off the table. More importantly, it could
incentivise more Brexiteer MPs to vote for the current deal, or face the prospect
of no Brexit altogether. This is particularly the case if all the EU27 offers in return
is a lengthy extension (i.e. to 2020 or beyond).
Regarding the near term outlook, votes on Wednesday will not be about an
amended Brexit agreement with the EU27, but rather the prospect of parliament
requesting an extension to Article 50 as highlighted above. Should either of
the two amendments prove successful, we would view this is as a positive
development. It is still true that a no deal Brexit could materialise if the extension
is short (i.e. to June), and no parliamentary consensus emerges by the end of the
extension.

BE11:24am

Following tomorrow's amendable motion, Prime Minister May has formally
committed to 12th March as the date for her meaningful vote on the amended
Withdrawal Agreement. As we do not anticipate that the EU Council will meet
by then, that vote will be on draft changes to the current Withdrawal Agreement
agreed with the Commission (rather than formal changes - which will have to be
signed off retrospectively on the 21-22nd March by the Council). This leaves a
potential banana skin if the EU Council were to make substantive changes to the
draft changes. This in turn could mean that any majority established on the 12th
by Prime Minister May might vanish by the time of the formal ratification vote in
the last week of March.
Note that the developments above has not removed the threat of a no deal Brexit
altogether. In particular, should Prime Minister May acknowledge that a request
for Article 50 extension will follow a rejection of changes to her Brexit deal on the
12th in Parliament, this could in turn increase the chances of it being rejected by
MPs. While a run down the clock strategy raised the risks of a no deal outcome,
it had the merit of keeping the pressure up on MPs to agree to the deal.

BE11:24am

God, I should've checked how long this was before starting .....

FJ Playing the Eagles' song in the Background while reading
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Recent developments have also increased the range of possible outcomes for the
Brexit endgame. While the Labour leadership changed policy last night to support
a new referendum based on a renegotiation of the Political Declaration on the
Future Relationship, we doubt that there exists a parliamentary majority for a
second referendum. However, the chances of a new election in May or June if PM
May is unable to secure a parliamentary majority for the Withdrawal Agreement
have risen. There also remains the prospect of a no deal outcome at the end of a
short extension in June. Our base case is that May is able to build a parliamentary
majority through changes to the Withdrawal Agreement by the end of March, but
the widening range of outcomes is reflected in updated probabilities below.
Notwithstanding, with the risk of a no deal Brexit now most likely off the table
by end March, as well as the increased effectiveness of coordination among prodeal
MPs, we see the price action of the last twenty four hours as justified, and
would look to reenter GBP longs, again targeting 0.84 in EUR/GBP. The key things
for the market to watch now are: is an extension to Article 50 should a deal not be
ratified by end March agreed this week in Parliament? what kind of extension is
offered in turn by the EU27 (a lengthier extension would increase the probability
Brexit is ratified by the end of March)?

BE11:25am

Sheesh, Okay, the always useful probabilities.

BE11:28am

We received a lot of pushback yesterday on our view that snap elections in the UK are becoming increasingly likely. The main
counter-argument presented was that enough anti-EU Conservatives from the European Research Group (ERG), Labour rebels and the DUP will swing their support behind the deal, securing Brexit (albeit not on 29 March) and the Conservative government. Crucial for this scenario is a concession from the EU on the Northern Ireland backstop, which allows the ERG and the DUP to save face. Crucial for that is an assurance from the attorney general Geoffrey Cox, a pro-Brexit Conservative himself, that the backstop does not permanently bind the UK. We see a significant risk that this will not work. The EU is unlikely to change the backstop in the withdrawal agreement and can merely commit on the speed of negotiations about a future trade deal and thus alternative arrangements for the Northern Irish borders, but not on the outcome of these negotiations. Knowing “no-deal” is effectively off the table and perhaps even encouraged by Labour’s pro-referendum turn, the EU has even less incentive to accommodate anti-EU politicians in the UK. If the “legal assurances” are not enough for the ERG (and the DUP), the Labour Party’s commitment to vote down the deal make it very difficult to see it pass. In that case the risk of new elections at the request of government or via a no confidence vote (the two paths under the 2011 Fixed Term Parliament Act) is very high, in our view, and Labour’s current weakness make it even more so.

BE11:35am

[W]hile the company guided for revenues of £5.2bn for FY2019 (slightly below our forecast of £5.3bn), it also guided for slightly higher underlying operating margins (we currently forecast -2% for FY2019, following 1H2019 at +1%). The company confirmed its net debt/EBITDA guidance for end 2019E of around 1.4x (GSf 1.5x) and also stated that it has continued with some further small business exits in the second half of the year as the company continues to refocus on the core business.
Babcock also highlighted some £20mn of exceptional costs linked with the UK exit from the EU (£10mn in tax and £10mn ongoing higher costs linked to the operations of the new structure), as well as £30mn linked to an adjustment to their pension liabilities following a recent High Court ruling in the UK on Lloyds banking Group in October (with the cash costs spread over the next six years). The pipeline and orderbook remained unchanged vs 1H.
The slightly lower than expected revenue guidance for the year is mostly due to lower revenues in the Rail business (Land division), lower business in South Africa, some lower procurement contracts in Marine and Aviation, as well as the recent business exits.

There was a focus during Q&A on the extra costs for Aerial Emergency Services post Brexit. Management were asked why this had arisen now rather than at the H1 results meeting given Brexit was an uncertainty then. Management said that in recent months their European clients had wanted more certainty about the post Brexit future so Babcock was effectively moving to a two company structure in each county to give customers confidence that Babcock’s licences would operate. More guidance on this additional cost of around £10m pa will be given at the results in May, when there may be more visibility on the post-Brexit requirement, although we think that given that the cost has been introduced it probably would not decline much in the event of a soft-Brexit. Management said that Babcock’s military businesses in the EU will not be impacted.

BE11:48am

BT’s normalised free cash flow of almost £2.5bn is c£1bn
higher than its dividend cost of £1.5bn. From this £1bn, BT has to support
the pension deficit, buy spectrum, buy back employee share options to
prevent dilution, and fund restructuring. If new CEO Philip Jansen wants
to increase investment to drive a return to growth, this would shrink the
£1bn of headroom for such costs, putting the dividend under pressure. We
thus see May’s full-year results as a risk and downgrade to Hold.

BE11:48am

(@Fatdaz: maybe, though I remember it as Lloyds. Might be two different cases.)

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Mr Jansen will reveal his strategy at May’s results. We believe he will outline a pro-investment, pro-growth vision and repair
political and regulatory relations at the start of his tenure. We do not think
BT has the cash flow to be able to do this without risk to the dividend. The
board has committed to 15.4p dividend in 2018/19 and 2019/20. We believe
that Mr Jansen may signal that, given the strategic importance and growth created by fibre-to-the-premise (FTTP), he will prioritise investment and signal a cut to the dividend from 2020/21. We forecast a 30% cut to 10.8p.

FATDAZ @BE my old memory is not what it was :(
BE11:49am

The most interesting bit, arguably, is on IFRS 16.

BE11:49am

We are slightly below consensus EBITDA in
the next few years, but it is at cash flow where we differ more. We forecast
capex rising to £3.9bn as BT accelerates FTTP and are more prudent on the scale of buybacks to offset employee share options (£150m in 2020/21E versus consensus at £47m). Net debt is increasing due to pension deficit payments, spectrum, restructuring and one-off tax phasing. Even once
these mostly normalise by 2020/21, consensus still has rising net debt.
IFRS 16 may also add £4bn-5bn to reported net debt as BT’s 2001 sale and
leaseback of its exchanges moves on balance sheet. Along with the pension deficit, this reminds us that BT’s balance sheet is not as strong as it appears at first glance.

FATDAZ @BE wasnt that recent this from FT adviser on Dec 4th 2018https://www.ftadviser.com/pensions/2018/12/04/bt-loses-high-court-case-to-cut-pension-benefits/

Travis Perkins’ FY results came in ahead of expectations, with PBT up 1%,
7% better than expected. The beat was driven by better than expected
interest as well as an improved contribution from Consumer after a strong
fourth quarter. We expect consensus estimates to be broadly unchanged, but
the market should be encouraged by news that progress is being made on
the Plumbing & Heating disposal and Wickes has stabilised. We note the
departure of COO Tony Buffin. The shares trade at 11.5x 2019E PER,
interesting given portfolio rationalisation and scope for improving market
trends post Brexit.

BornCynic Regarding Brexit - I have absolute faith in our politicians to do what is right and best for the country. Which is why I went out and filled my boots with IBTM.
BE11:59am

We find ourselves one of only three buyers of the stock (out of 21 covering analysts), having been
consistently over-optimistic on delivery of results from the improvement programme. There are grounds
for optimism here amongst the gloom: sentiment is at an all-time low, short interest is still reasonable
(c3%), estimates are now pretty conservative, there is hope of upside from the disposal of Plumbing &
Heating, and possibly Wickes, as well as cost savings. The market backdrop is dull, but more stable than
widely feared, and we find a 9% FCF yield compelling for a market leader poised to exploit its scale more
effectively.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Elliott-Hammerson? Okay. Here's Numis to outline the prisoner's dilemma they've managed to get themselves into.

BE12:02pm

HMSO is stuck in a difficult place. LTV is too high at a time of deflating values and virtually no liquidity in investment markets, yet the need to maintain defensive capex levels is high. Adding to the complexity is the presence of activist investor Elliott Advisors who is pushing mgmt to step up disposal plans in order to provide a short term upgrade to the equity rating with seemingly little thought to the longer term impact on the portfolio. With further valuation downside expected, the impact of disposals on earnings will be exacerbated; mgmt may have guided to dividend stability, but we see rising risk of a dividend cut should pricing prove weaker than currently anticipated as the payout ratio rises. Over the longer term, our concern is that LTV will remain high (greater than 35% vs HMSO’s internal 40% cap) which means HMSO looks set to be ‘managed for leverage’ rather than ‘managed for growth’. With such elevated execution risks and a lack of future growth opportunities, we believe HMSO is one to avoid despite the apparently wide 50% discount to NAV.
